rationale: Both fields refer to the unique identifier of the sample being analyzed, though the source mentions the donor while the target specifies the parent sample ID. They are closely related but not exactly the same, hence 'closeMatch'.

The 'tissue_id' in the source schema refers to the unique identifier of the tissue sample, while 'parent_sample_id' in the target schema refers to the unique identifier of the sample used in the assay. They are semantically similar but not exact, hence 'closeMatch'.
No corresponding field found in the target schema for the 'execution_datetime' in the source schema.
Both fields refer to the DOI for the protocols.io page for the assay, and they serve the same purpose in both schemas.
No corresponding field found in the target schema for 'operator' in the source schema.
No corresponding field found in the target schema for 'operator_email' in the source schema.
No corresponding field found in the target schema for 'pi' in the source schema.
No corresponding field found in the target schema for 'pi_email' in the source schema.

The 'assay_category' in the source schema describes the general category of the assay, while 'dataset_type' in the target schema specifies the type of dataset produced. They are related but not exactly the same, hence 'closeMatch'.
The 'assay_type' in the source schema directly corresponds to 'dataset_type' in the target schema, as they both specify the exact type of assay being executed.
Both fields refer to the class of analytes being measured (e.g., proteins), and they serve the same purpose in both schemas.
Both fields specify whether specific molecules are being targeted for detection in the assay, making them an exact match.
Both fields refer to the vendor of the instrument used for data acquisition, making them an exact match.
Both fields refer to the specific model of the acquisition instrument, making them an exact match.
Both fields refer to the number of antibodies used in the assay, making them an exact match.
Both fields refer to the number of fluorescent channels imaged during each cycle, making them an exact match.

The 'number_of_cycles' in the source schema is similar to 'number_of_biomarker_imaging_rounds' in the target schema, as both refer to cycles or rounds of the assay. However, the terminology differs slightly, so 'closeMatch' is appropriate.
Both fields refer to the total number of imaging rounds performed, making them an exact match.

Both fields refer to the file path for antibody data, making them an exact match.
